thread.title: What was the North East voting turnout in the EU referendum?
thread.title_full: What was the North East voting turnout in the EU referendum?

author: Helen Dalby
title: What was the North East voting turnout in the EU referendum?
text:
What was the North East voting turnout in the EU referendum? 10:05, 24 Jun 2016 The North East emphatically voted in favour of leaving the EU in the referendum, with a 58% vote share for a Brexit Shares Comments Get daily news by email Trays for ballot papers wait to be filled at the start of the North East region European Union referendum count on June 23, 2016 in Sunderland 
The North East voter turnout was 1.34 million across the region - and of these voters, 778,103 opted to leave the EU and 562,595 sided with remain. 
Of the North East authorities, only Newcastle marginally voted to remain. All of the seven North East authority results are listed in full below. 
Nationwide it became clear at around 4.45am on Friday as counting continued that the Leave campaign had won, with around 52% of the national vote. BBC analysts calculated it was impossible for the remain campaign to win, based on the votes counted so far. 
Also read: EU Referendum LIVE: David Cameron to step down as PM by October after leave vote 
The nationâ€™s decision was a victory for the Leave campaign backed by Boris Johnson, the senior Conservative seen as the most likely candidate to succeed David Cameron as Tory leader. 
David Cameron announced his intention to resign in the wake of the EU referendum result on Friday morning in a political earthquake which has sent shockwaves around the world. 
Below, we list the final EU referendum results by North East local authority as well as the voter turnout by area. 
Turnout was highest in North Tyneside, where 72% of the electorate went to the polls. 
Average voter turnout in England was 73%. NEWCASTLE
